isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (NAVPAK) (1997) - SECTION 2.2: HARD START/NO START DIAGNOSTICS - T 444E ENGINE - EST TOOL-DATA LIST

svcprocinfo.para:
Refer to Table 2.11
for the EST Tool-Data List.

table.title: Table 2.11 EST Tool-Data List FROM FORM EGED-195

entry.para: • Select and enter following data as the first three lines in a custom data list
• Monitor the data while cranking the engine for 20 seconds minimum

para.emph: If voltage is low, proceed to test 9a.
If no RPM is noted, recheck fault codes and proceed to test 9b.
If ICP pressure is low, refer to diagnostic publication EGES-190 for system leakage tests

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if the components needed for starting are operating within specifications.

svcsubproc.title: Test Procedure

important.para: TEST MUST BE PERFORMED WITH FULLY CHARGED BATTERIES.

svcsubproc.para: To measure engine cranking speed, battery voltage, and Injection Control Pressure (ICP), it may be possible to read the data on the Electronic Service Tool (EST), "DATA LIST", while the engine is cranking. If the voltage drops below 7 volts while cranking, the EST tool will "RESET" back to start-up. If this happens, the tool can be used to perform this test by setting a "Custom Data List" to conduct "Testing Voltage, RPM and ICP individually" using the Fluke 88 DVOM as an alternative.

note.para: Turn all accessories and the ignition off, before connecting EST tool to ATA diagnostic connector.

svcsubproc.para: Connect the EST tool to the American Trucking Association (ATA) diagnostic connector. The connector is located on the lower left kick panel inside the cab. The screen of the reader should light up as soon as the tool is plugged in.

Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position. Do not start the engine. This will allow the EST to receive data from the electronic control components on the truck. The information received will be data indicating the current status of the engine ( Figure 2.18
).

Press the "↓" key until "BATT VOLTS" appears on the screen. Continue to press the "↓" key until the black dot is on "BATT VOLTS". Pressing the number "0" key, will add "BATT VOLTS" to the custom data list. Press "FUNC" to return to Standard Data List ( Figure 2.19
).

Now press the "↓" key until the black dot is on "ENGINE RPM". Press the number "0" key to add "ENGINE RPM" to the custom data list ( Figure 2.20
).

Press "FUNC"key to return to Navistar Engine Control Module data list. Continue to press the"↓" key until "INJ CNTL PSI" is highlighted with the black dot. Then press the number "0" key to add "INJ CNTL PSI" on the Custom Data List ( Figure 2.21
).

figure.caption: Figure 2.21 Update To Custom Data Screen

svcsubproc.para: The EST is now ready to read data. Crank the engine while observing the data on the screen.

The battery voltage must be 7 or more volts. If the voltage to the Electronic Control Module (ECM) drops below 7 volts, the ECM will not remain powered up. If the ECM is not receiving power via the ECM relay, the engine cannot be started.
Engine cranking RPM must be sufficient to generate the required Injection Control Pressure to operate the fuel injectors and to create enough compression heat to ignite the fuel.

A "0" RPM indication on the Electronic Service Tool (EST) during engine cranking, indicates the ECM may not be receiving a signal from the Camshaft Position (CMP) sensor. Refer to CMP sensor diagnostics in Section 3, Electronic Control System Diagnostics.
If the CMP sensor is inoperative, it must be repaired before continuing. The ECM will not allow the Injector Pressure Regulator (IPR) valve to fully activate without a CMP signal.
If the EST indicates little or no injection control pressure check oil level in oil reservoir.

Remove the inspection plug located on top of the oil reservoir and check the level of oil in the reservoir. Normal oil level is within 1/2 inch from the top of the reservoir. Filling the reservoir will allow the system to prime faster facilitating starting.
If the oil level in the reservoir becomes low while vehicle is parked for a short period of time, it is due to a leaking check valve in the high pressure pump.
If the oil level in the reservoir becomes low while cranking the engine, this is an indication that oil is not being pumped to the reservoir.

item.para: Low battery voltage. - Due to "bad" batteries, high resistance at battery cable connections or in the wiring to the ECM.
Blown 40A inline fuse (located in battery box) which supplies battery power (voltage) to ECM.
Low cranking RPM. - May be caused by electrical system malfunctions, incorrect oil or extended oil change intervals in cold ambient temperatures.
No engine RPM indication on EST while cranking the engine. - CMP sensor or faulty circuitry to the ECM may cause this condition. Recheck for fault codes after cranking engine. (Refer to Test 5 or 7).
Low ICP Pressure-May indicate a leak in the high pressure oil system or a defective CMP sensor.

A defective high pressure oil pump or pump drive will prevent proper injection control pressure. A defective Injection Pressure Regulator (IPR), or electronic controls for the regulator will cause low injection control pressure.

svcsubproc.title: Tools Required
svcsubproc.para: PRO-LINK 9000 (ZTSE-43661)

item.para: Low voltage at ECM. - Refer to Electronic Control System Diagnostics, (Section 3-Electronic Control Module Power Circuit (ECM PWR).
No Engine RPM indication during engine cranking. - Refer to CMP sensor diagnostics in Electronic Control System Diagnostics Section 3.
No Injection Control Pressure. - Refer to Injection Control Pressure (ICP) sensor, IPR valve diagnostics in Electronic Control System Diagnostics Section 3.
No or low injection control pressure and no electronic faults. - Refer to HIGH PRESSURE LEAKAGE TESTS.

svcsubproc.title: Creating A Custom Data List
svcsubproc.para:
From the main menu select "Engine Data List" and press "ENTER" ( Figure 2.22
).

Press the "↓" key until the black dot appears on the PID to be added to the Custom Data List. Then press the number "0" key. The selected PID will now be added to the bottom of the Custom Data List ( Figure 2.23
).

figure.caption: Figure 2.23 Adding Data To The Custom Data List Screen

svcsubproc.para:
Pressing the " FUNC" key one time will toggle back to Standard Data List ( Figure 2.24
).

Using the "↓" or "↑"key to highlight the next PID for the Custom Data List with the black dot depress the "0" key to add PID to bottom of Custom Data List ( Figure 2.25
).
To remove a PID from the Custom Data List, move the black dot with the "↑↓"key to the desired PID and press the "0" key. This will remove the PID from the Custom Data List.

If the tool cycles on and off, due to low voltage it will now return to the screen "START NEW SESSION" ( Figure 2.26
).
Press the "→" key to move brackets to "NO". Pressing ENTERwill cause the EST to toggle back to the Custom Data List.
